captions.text: Cadmium?
Yes
Ok
Oh yeah, that’s some! That is cool man!

So cadmium is an element which is really quite
similar to

mercury and the way that most people have
seen cadmium is

that cadmium sulphide has a very strong orange
colour and it

is therefore used for dying things yellow
or orange. If you

look round your house or your parents’ house,
you may easily

find a cast iron pot which has, a cooking
pot, which has nice

orange sides and orange lid and this is using
cadmium
sulphide as a glaze.

So this is a sample which was generated or
which was used

by some of our researchers in the School of
Chemistry many

years ago and this is a sample of cadmium
metal. Now it’s

very interesting because it is stored in this
really quite nice

box which was perhaps a medication that somebody
had
bought, but if we open it…

It's also I believe, to colour the plastic
pipe that you see in

the street for gas pipes and so on. I think
it is coloured with a

cadmium compound. Now in both these applications,
even

though that cadmium is quite poisonous, that
they are so

strongly fixed into the materials that it
isn’t a threat to
people.

And we can see the lumps of the metallic cadmium.
Now I am

not going to touch the cadmium because we
know of some of

the issues with toxicity. But it is used very
often in batteries,

or it was traditionally used in batteries.
It is really important

that we dispose of our batteries in a correct
way.

comments.text:
Cadmium is still used, btw, it's just adviced not to. So I guess it's not 
as poisonous, or at least the combounds used in paint aren't. There are of 
course safer options nowadays. Btw, apparently "Cadmium Yellow" is the 
poisonous one but "Cadmium Yellow Hue" doesn't contain any cadmium, it's 
just named so since it's a substitute for it.
comments.author: Tuuliska

comments.text:
I'm an amateur artist so I immediately think of yellow when I hear 
"cadmium". :D It's funny btw, when I was taking a class on painting, it 
felt like half of the paints were said to be poisonous. Some are so 
poisonous that they aren't legal to use anymore. Arsenic for green and 
yellow, for example, lead for white, yellow and red, mercury for orange... 
and so on. (But some "hard core" painters still do, of course...) No wonder 
painters used to get sick and go crazy all the time back in the day.
comments.author: Tuuliska

comments.text:
CdS quantum dots give off that nice blue emission upon excitation. well the 
colour emission and colour transmitted are completely complementary. if it 
emits blue, it transmits orange cos it absorbs blue light in the spectrum. 
working with CdS quantum dots now, periodic videos shld do a video on 
quantum dots! pretty interesting colours there!

comments.text:
Actually because glass is so dense and inert its very hard to make toxic. 
Cadmium glass, and even uranium glass, are both perfectly safe to handle on 
a day-to-day basis, because all the toxic particles are completely encased 
by very safe glass.

comments.text:
People, don't panic. Cadmium Is still used in the electroplating industry. 
My company plated with cadmium and we handled cad Daily. Just dont eat it 
or lick your hands after you touch it. It just like handling lead. Wash 
your hands and don't eat the shit. Aerospace always wants their parts 
cadmium plated over zinc, because cadmium protects against rust better.

comments.author: douro20

comments.text:
Cadmium has a low melting point. It's used in Wood's metal, Indalloy-117, 
and Cerrobend, and a certain alloy was used in Terminator 2 for some 
special effects of the T-1000 (liquid Terminator). It's pretty amazing how 
many elements and chemicals we use and are exposed too in our everyday 
lives. The extremely rare mineral, esp. in gemstone form, Greenockite is 
CdS. Sphalerite is similar, but consists of Zinc instead (ZnS). Activated 
ZnS (Zinc Sulfide) will glow if it's exposed to alpha particles.

comments.text:
A role of cadmium in biology has been recently discovered. A 
cadmium-dependent carbonic anhydrase has been found in marine diatoms. Cd 
does the same job as Zn in other anhydrases, but the diatoms live in 
environments with very low Zn concentrations, thus biology has taken Cd 
rather than Zn, and made it work. It has been said that Cd is an essential 
part of the Earth's biosphere, which goes against the previously held view 
that it's nothing but toxic and serves no ecological purpose.

eventually replaced with tin plating, which is much less toxic.
